I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the additional financing of the Greater 
Mekong Subregion Health Security Project.1 
 
2.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the ongoing project on 22 November 2016 
for  $125  million  equivalent  from  its  ordinary  capital  resources.2 Building  on  ADB’s  prior 
investments in communicable disease control (CDC) in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS),3 
the ongoing project aims to strengthen regional cooperation and subnational CDC systems, 
particularly in border areas. The impact of the ongoing project is strengthened GMS public health 
security.  The  outcome  is  GMS  health  system  performance  with  regard  to  health  security 
improved. As of 7 May 2020, the Lao PDR has officially reported 19 confirmed coronavirus 
disease (COVID-19) cases, with evidence of limited local transmission.4 While the cases remain 
relatively limited, there are serious concerns about the level of preparedness in the event of any 
pandemic resurgence. The proposed additional financing for the Lao PDR aims to scale up the 
ongoing project’s interventions in emerging infectious diseases, particularly COVID-19.5 It will 
support the Government of the Lao PDR’s National Preparedness and Response Plan for COVID-
19,6 which aims to mitigate the impact of possible large-scale community transmission and 
improve pandemic preparedness. The additional financing will address the immediate needs for 
procuring and distributing essential medical supplies and equipment, scaling up capacity for 
laboratory testing and case management, and strengthening the health system for coping with 
similar emerging infectious disease outbreaks in the medium and long term. The report and 
recommendation of the President for the ongoing project is accessible from the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 2. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
3.  The proposed project meets the eligibility criteria for additional financing. The impact and 
outcome of the project remain unchanged. The implementation of the ongoing project in the Lao 
PDR is on track as of 30 April 2020. Against an elapsed time of 59%, cumulative contract awards 
for the loan and grant are $7.05 million (59% of ADB financing), and cumulative disbursements 
are $8.51 million (71% of ADB financing). All safeguard and financial covenants have either been 
achieved or are being complied with.7 The delivery of expected outputs is rated successful, and 
the project is on track to achieve the intended output and outcome indicators. The identified

4.  The additional financing interventions are aligned with outputs 2 and 3 of the ongoing 
project to improve surveillance and strengthen the laboratory system and hospital infection 
prevention and control (IPC). The additional investment in lab testing and hospital service capacity 
will meet the greater than anticipated need during any COVID-19 outbreak that the country may 
experience when the economy opens up after the current containment measures are relaxed 
(para. 6). The project interventions will be expanded from 15 to all 17 provinces of the Lao PDR. 
The  existing  project  management  unit  can  expedite  implementation  of  the  new  activities. 
Therefore, the additional financing is considered the most responsive and appropriate approach 
for delivering the urgently needed assistance. The proposed additional financing has been 
determined to be technically feasible, economically viable, and financially sound (Table 3). 
  
5.  The GMS Health Sector Working Group8 met in December 2019 and reconfirmed their 
strong  commitment  to  regional  health  security  and  achieving  the  core  capacities  of  the 
International Health Regulations (2005).9 They endorsed the GMS Health Cooperation Strategy 
2019-2023,10 which the project continues to support. The overall project remains consistent with 
the ADB Strategy 2030,11 and ADB’s country partnership strategy for the Lao PDR, 2017–2020, 
which prioritizes investment for enhanced human development.12  
 
6.  The Lao PDR is highly vulnerable to the COVID-19 pandemic as many migrant workers 
are returning from heavily affected neighboring countries.13 The National Preparedness and 
Response Plan has projected that in the scenario of widespread community transmission, the 
country could have 20,000 cases at the peak, of which about 4,500 will be severe or critical cases 
that need hospitalization. Although the country has made steady progress under previous and 
ongoing CDC projects (footnote 2) to improve the response capacity to emerging infectious 
diseases, its health system remains weak and could be overwhelmed by rapid spread of the virus. 
At the end of 2019, the Lao PDR had 190 beds for critical care, 74 working ventilators, and only 
118 doctors and 222 nurses working in intensive care units in all central and provincial hospitals. 
The three central reference laboratories can perform about 300 COVID-19 confirmation tests per 
day, whereas the plan targets at scaling up to 1,000 tests per day including adding capacity in 
selected  provinces.  Further,  the  country faces  a  severe  shortage  of medical  supplies  and 
equipment to mitigate the impact of possible large-scale community transmission. This includes 
(i) personal protective equipment (e.g., masks, gowns, goggles, and gloves) and disinfectants; (ii) 
laboratory  equipment, testing  kits,  and  other  consumables;  (iii) equipment  and  supplies  for 
supportive treatment in hospitals;14 and (iv) ambulances and other vehicles. The government has 
requested the proposed additional financing to procure part of the supplies and equipment on 
their master procurement list.15 In addition, rapid training on IPC and case management for

B.  Project Description 
 
7.  The project impact and outcome will remain the same. The additional financing proposes 
a new output: emergency response to the COVID-19 outbreak supported (output 4). The main 
activities under output 4 include: (i) the procurement and distribution of medical supplies and 
equipment (items in para. 6) to hospitals at all levels according to needs, including equipping 
Luang Prabang, Savannakhet, and Champasak, three of the largest provinces in the Lao PDR, 
with COVID-19 confirmation test capacity of about 150-180 per day in each province. (ii) rapid 
training for frontline health workers on IPC, lab testing, and clinical care for COVID-19; and (iii) 
some non-pharmaceutical interventions, including risk communications and contact tracing. While 
the activities fall within the scope of outputs 2 and 3 of the ongoing project, a new output is 
proposed for effectiveness and efficiency in administration and monitoring. The revised design 
and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
C.  Value Added by ADB   
 
8.  ADB is a trusted and leading development partner in the health sector in the Lao PDR, 
with more than two decades of continuous engagement. Through the ongoing project and the 
Health Sector Governance Program,16 ADB has supported the government’s Health Sector 
Reform Strategy, including strengthening communicable disease surveillance and response. The 
ongoing project supported Ministry of Health (MOH)’s procurement of the first batch of COVID-19 
response supplies and equipment in March 2020. The strategic long-term investment in CDC as 
a regional public good in the GMS may have contributed to the relatively well-managed COVID-
19 outbreak in the subregion so far.17 A new project under preparation since 2019 will focus on 
improving the quality of health care and achieving universal health coverage by 2025. The Lao 
PDR benefits from regional knowledge platforms hosted by ADB for knowledge sharing and 
regional cooperation through ongoing technical assistance on GMS health cooperation.18  
 
9.  Since the onset of the COVID-19 pandemic, ADB has quickly responded to requests from 
Southeast Asian countries with timely, scaled, coordinated, and practical solutions that meet the 
needs of governments.19 To facilitate rapid assistance to COVID-19 response, ADB applies a 
streamlined approval process and more flexible procurement rules.20 ADB has also established 
strategic  partnerships  with  other  multilateral  and  bilateral  agencies,  and  facilitated  project 
procurement planning by linking the MOH with credible global suppliers to cope with the volatility 
of the global supply market for COVID-19 medical equipment and consumables. In the Lao PDR,

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  The additional financing entails no major changes to the implementation arrangements. 
The MOH, represented by the Department of Planning and Cooperation, remains the executing 
agency in the Lao PDR. Two additional provincial health offices will be added as implementing 
agencies.23 The project will engage international procurement agents to facilitate the procurement 
of goods. The implementation arrangements are described in detail in the project administration 
manual (footnote 22).

IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
16.  The Government of the Lao PDR has assured ADB that implementation of the project 
shall conform to all applicable ADB requirements including those concerning anticorruption 
measures, safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, financial management, and 
disbursement as described in detail in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
The government has agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, which are set forth in 
the loan agreement.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
17.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of $20 million 
to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic for the additional financing of the Greater Mekong 
Subregion Health Security Project, from ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in concessional terms, 
with an interest charge at the rate of 1.0% per year during the grace period and 1.5% per year 
thereafter; for a term of 32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and 
conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement 
presented to the Board.

The proposed additional financing for the Lao PDR aims to scale up the ongoing project’s interventions in emerging infectious diseases, particularly COVID-19. It will support the Government of the Lao PDR’s National Preparedness and Response Plan for COVID- 19, which aims to mitigate the impact of possible large-scale community transmission and improve pandemic preparedness.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated May 2020 is provided for the ADB project 48118-003 in the Lao People's Democratic Republic.
